liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Smith South Australia's Opposition Leader David Speirs and Liberal Senator Kerrynne Liddle, who are both advocating for a No vote, spoke outside a pre-polling booth in the coastal suburb of Brighton this morning. Mr Speirs urged people to "remain respectful and decent" during the voting process. "This is an important part of democracy and we ought to respect it and respect each other's views," he said. Mr Speirs said South Australians he had spoken to were "confused" about the Voice. "They're really concerned about the serious lack of detail that has been put on the table by the prime minister. And the prime minister is going to have a lot of questions to answer on Sunday morning if, as predicted, the referendum is defeated across Australia," he said. Ms Liddle, an Arrernte woman, said people should focus on the facts when they make their decision, not emotion. "It is about a whole new chapter in our constitution, in our nation's rulebook, and anything you do to our rulebook has consequences," she said. "That's why Australians have been very careful historically in making any change to our rulebook — and they should be. "And they should be really careful on this one too, because they shouldn't be voting on emotion. "They shouldn't be voting because they feel like they're being intimidated, harassed, or ashamed or guilted. None of those things should come into play here."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: State Opposition Leader David Speirs says South Australians 'confused' about Voice

children.content: South Australian opposition leader David Speirs and Liberal Senator Kerrynne Liddle
(ABC News)
Reporting by Matt Smith
South Australia's Opposition Leader
David Speirs
and Liberal Senator
Kerrynne Liddle
, who are both advocating for a No vote, spoke outside a pre-polling booth in the coastal suburb of Brighton this morning.
Mr Speirs urged people to "remain respectful and decent" during the voting process.
"This is an important part of democracy and we ought to respect it and respect each other's views," he said.
Mr Speirs said South Australians he had spoken to were "confused" about the Voice.

"They're really concerned about the serious lack of detail that has been put on the table by the prime minister. And the prime minister is going to have a lot of questions to answer on Sunday morning if, as predicted, the referendum is defeated across Australia," he said.
Ms Liddle, an Arrernte woman, said people should focus on the facts when they make their decision, not emotion.
"It is about a whole new chapter in our constitution, in our nation's rulebook, and anything you do to our rulebook has consequences," she said.
"That's why Australians have been very careful historically in making any change to our rulebook — and they should be.
"And they should be really careful on this one too, because they shouldn't be voting on emotion.
"They shouldn't be voting because they feel like they're being intimidated, harassed, or ashamed or guilted. None of those things should come into play here."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NOPE. Voting more than once constitutes electoral fraud. According to the AEC's own background document on electoral fraud, a person found to have voted multiple times could be imprisoned for up to 12 months for each fraudulent additional vote (that is, a person who votes three times could face 24 months in jail, or 36 months if they voted four times). "Multiple voting under the Electoral Act or the Referendum Act may take the form of a person voting more than once under their own name," the backgrounder explains. "For example, where a person attends more than one polling place on election day or votes more than once using early or postal voting." A social post from the AEC noted that instances of multiple voting "have never been of a significant volume and never more than the margin in an election". "We have electronic certified lists across all pre-polls and continuing to many on-the-day polling places with real-time mark-off of the roll." Read more referendum misinformation debunking below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Can you legally vote in the referendum multiple times?

featuredLink.title: Don't do this to your ballot paper if you want your vote to count in the referendum

children.content: NOPE.
Voting more than once constitutes electoral fraud.
According to the AEC's
own background document

on electoral fraud, a person found to have voted multiple times could be imprisoned for up to 12 months for each fraudulent additional vote (that is, a person who votes three times could face 24 months in jail, or 36 months if they voted four times).
"Multiple voting under the Electoral Act or the Referendum Act may take the form of a person voting more than once under their own name," the backgrounder explains.
"For example, where a person attends more than one polling place on election day or votes more than once using early or postal voting."
A social post from the AEC noted that instances of multiple voting "have never been of a significant volume and never more than the margin in an election".
"We have electronic certified lists across all pre-polls and continuing to many on-the-day polling places with real-time mark-off of the roll."
Read more referendum misinformation debunking below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysis by indigenous affairs editor Bridget Brennan At an Aboriginal health clinic in Melbourne this week I asked an elder how she was planning on voting. She whispered, "I'm not sure". She hadn't voted early because she needed more time to make up her mind. "All these words — reconciliation, recognition — what happened to land rights?" she asked. Another young woman said she would vote Yes because it's "what my nan would have done". This debate is serious business. And First Nations people at the coalface of closing the gap are aggrieved and horrified at the toll this is taking. Read more of Bridget's perspective below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Indigenous people deserve so much more than the Voice debate we were subjected to'

featuredLink.title: The Voice debate has put the worst of Australia on display. Indigenous people deserve better

children.content: Analysis by indigenous affairs editor Bridget Brennan
More than four million Australians have already visited the pre-polls.
(AAP: Joel Carrett)

At an Aboriginal health clinic in Melbourne this week I asked an elder how she was planning on voting. She whispered, "I'm not sure". She hadn't voted early because she needed more time to make up her mind.
"All these words — reconciliation, recognition — what happened to land rights?" she asked. Another young woman said she would vote Yes because it's "what my nan would have done".
This debate is serious business. And First Nations people at the coalface of closing the gap are aggrieved and horrified at the toll this is taking.
Read more of Bridget's perspective below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Aside from the already announced Qantas flights leaving Israel for London in the coming days, the Australian government has now announced at least two charter flights which will take Australians from Tel Aviv to Dubai. Foreign Affairs Minister Penny Wong and Transport Minister Catherine King say Qantas has also agreed to fly Australians arriving in London (from Tel Aviv) to Sydney via Singapore free of charge. "The Australian government will continue to work on options for onward travel from Dubai and to support those who cannot reach Tel Aviv," the ministers say in a press release. The government says Australians in Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories who want to leave and don't already have plans to depart should register via DFAT's Crisis Porta l or by calling the 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian government announces more repatriation flights from Israel

children.content: Aside from the already announced Qantas flights leaving Israel for London in the coming days, the Australian government has now announced at least two charter flights which will take Australians from Tel Aviv to Dubai.

"The Australian government will continue to work on options for onward travel from Dubai and to support those who cannot reach Tel Aviv," the ministers say in a press release.
The government says Australians in Israel or the Occupied Palestinian Territories who want to leave and don't already have plans to depart should register via

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More than 423,000 people have now been forced to flee their homes in the Gaza Strip, the United Nations says. The number of displaced Gazans rose by an additional 84,444 people as of late Thursday, the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said. AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More than 423,000 Gazans now displaced, UN says

props.alt: Man kisses son in front of blue background

children.content: Displaced Palestinian Ali Wahdan kisses his son inside a makeshift shelter in Gaza.
(Reuters )
More than 423,000 people have now been forced to flee their homes in the Gaza Strip, the United Nations says.
The number of displaced Gazans rose by an additional 84,444 people as of late Thursday, the UN's Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs said.
AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW Police are urging people to avoid heading into the CBD of Sydney on Sunday, where the Palestine Action Group plans to hold a rally in support of the residents of Gaza. Police have conceded they do not have powers to stop the rally going ahead, but any march has been banned. Acting Commissioner Dave Hudson says it's hoped legal advice will be provided by tomorrow, to support police plans to ensure public safety. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW Police considers special powers for pro-Palestinian rally

featuredLink.title: NSW Police considering using 'extraordinary' powers at planned Sydney pro-Palestinian rally

children.content: NSW Police are urging people to avoid heading into the CBD of Sydney on Sunday, where the Palestine Action Group plans to hold a rally in support of the residents of Gaza.
Police have conceded they do not have powers to stop the rally going ahead, but any march has been banned.
Acting Commissioner Dave Hudson says it's hoped legal advice will be provided by tomorrow, to support police plans to ensure public safety.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Lions have released a statement regarding Gunston's request to return to Hawthorn. "The Brisbane Lions confirm Jack Gunston has informed the club of his desire to return to Hawthorn. "While understanding Jack's situation, as a contracted player the club is assessing its position and will work through its options. "The club won't be providing further comment at this time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Brisbane confirm Jack Gunston trade request

children.content: (Getty Images)
The Lions have released a statement regarding Gunston's request to return to Hawthorn.
"The Brisbane Lions confirm Jack Gunston has informed the club of his desire to return to Hawthorn.
"While understanding Jack's situation, as a contracted player the club is assessing its position and will work through its options.
"The club won't be providing further comment at this time."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I am surprised to hear Gunston's name in trade rumours. What would the Lions get from Hawthorn if there was a deal? - Leo. Not very much, I would imagine. From all reports, the Hawks are a bit surprised by this as well and haven't exactly been preparing for it. If Hawthorn are interested in bringing him back, I can't see them offering a whole lot to make it happen. Last year the Lions payed pick 48 and a future fourth for him. I doubt the Hawks will even go that far this time around. Whether that means Gunston stays in Brisbane or if another Victorian club tries to get involved remains to be seen.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A Jack Gunston surprise

children.content: I am surprised to hear Gunston's name in trade rumours. What would the Lions get from Hawthorn if there was a deal?
- Leo
Not very much, I would imagine.
(Getty Images)

From all reports, the Hawks are a bit surprised by this as well and haven't exactly been preparing for it. If Hawthorn are interested in bringing him back, I can't see them offering a whole lot to make it happen.
Last year the Lions payed pick 48 and a future fourth for him. I doubt the Hawks will even go that far this time around.
Whether that means Gunston stays in Brisbane or if another Victorian club tries to get involved remains to be seen.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Herald Sun and SEN are reporting the Bombers are about to get their man. They say the offer has gone in and St Kilda is happy with the compensation offered by the AFL. Can only presume that means an end-of-first-round pick is heading their way. As a result the Saints will not match the Essendon offer, and Jade Gresham will soon become a Bomber. Confirmation from the AFL shouldn't be far away. Good result all round, and I reckon that news might unlock a whole stack of other deals.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Essendon are set to land Jade Gresham

children.content: (Getty Images)
The Herald Sun and SEN are reporting the Bombers are about to get their man.
They say the offer has gone in and St Kilda is happy with the compensation offered by the AFL. Can only presume that means an end-of-first-round pick is heading their way.
As a result the Saints will not match the Essendon offer, and Jade Gresham will soon become a Bomber.
Confirmation from the AFL shouldn't be far away.
Good result all round, and I reckon that news might unlock a whole stack of other deals.

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: The latest data out of the US shows inflation is sticking around, which is leading investors to worry that regulators there will start raising rates again soon. Meanwhile, experts warn that if the Israel-Gaza war escalates it has the "potential to certainly derail markets". Read all about it as it happens on our live blog.

title.children: Inflation data reignites interest rate fears on Wall Street and ASX, while Israel-Gaza war sparks recession fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The world's largest gold miner is set to take over Newcrest Mining after the Australian company's investors resoundingly voted in favour of this happening. Proxy votes came in at 91.66% in favour this morning, a slide shown to investors at a meeting in Melbourne showed. Newcrest Corporation's $26.2 billion bid for the company will be the largest corporate buyout in Australia this year. In May, Newcrest backed the takeover offer from Newmont. Both the companies expect the deal to close in early November. A final result will become known later on Friday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investors approve the biggest corporate buyout in Australia this year

children.content: The world's largest gold miner is set to take over Newcrest Mining after the Australian company's investors resoundingly voted in favour of this happening.
Proxy votes came in at 91.66% in favour this morning, a slide shown to investors at a meeting in Melbourne showed.
Newcrest Corporation's $26.2 billion bid for the company will be the largest corporate buyout in Australia this year.
In May,
Newcrest
backed the takeover offer from Newmont.
Both the companies expect the
deal to close in early November.
A final result will become known later on Friday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow. The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same. That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes. This note from CBA this morning: Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession. Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US inflation and Israel-Gaza war sparks global recession concerns

featuredLink.title: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

children.content: Good morning!
The latest inflation data out of the US is spooking markets this morning. As you will see, Wall Street ended in the red and the futures for Australian markets show we will likely follow.
The CPI data shows that price hikes aren't over in the world's biggest economy, with headline rising above consensus estimates by 0.3% a month and core inflation about the same.
That, of course, is creating concern that the US federal reserve will raise rates again to tackle price spikes.
This note from CBA this morning:

Notwithstanding, we doubt the downtrend in inflation has been thrown off course.  The outlook for the US consumer is poor given the resumption of student loan repayments, lower government benefit payments, and the erosion of pandemic savings.  At the same time, interest rates on consumer loans have risen sharply to very high levels.  Indeed, some FOMC officials have recently said the rise in yields may substitute for further FOMC tightening.  Our baseline remains for the FOMC to keep the Funds rate steady into early 2024.  We consider the FOMC’s significant policy tightening will lead the global economy into recession.
Recession fears are also being sparked by the devastating crisis in the Middle East. Here is a piece by our business reporter Nassim Khadem to get you started this morning.
